docs.lead_paragraph: THE NUMBER of jobs in the nation continues to expand, and following this expansion has come widespread industrial growth. According to predictions by the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics, even moderate economic generation will increase the labor force 15 percent by 1995, to 129 million, from the current 111.6 million, including members of the armed forces serving in this country. Many observers say job growth will be substantial next year,though the manufacturing sector continues to lag and, the bureau says, slowdown in job growth is occurring in some service sectors. If present growth continues, the nation, with slightly less than 7 percent unemployed, will have 120 million jobs by the end of 1987. But the B.L.S. says that job growth will be slower in the remainder of this decade and the first half of the 1990's than in previous recent periods.

headline.main: Job Forecast: Sunny With Some Clouds

docs.lead_paragraph: At a time when medical experts increasingly recognize the element of compassion as an essential aid in the healing process, several circumstances in New York City's hospitals continue to make them among the worst when it comes to treating patients like people, not just bed numbers or diseases. Mr. Leonard's back surgery, for example, was unquestionably a success. He had entered New York University Hospital in mid-September with such pain in his right leg that he could hardly even lie down. On the first day after surgery, he was able to walk without discomfort. Then his troubles began: a fever that soared to over 104, a possible spot of pneumonia and urinary retention, all followed by an itchy rash that covered him from head to toe.
